rbiom 1.0.3.9062

Create a heatmap with tracks and dendrograms from any matrix.

Source: R/plot_heatmap.r
plot_heatmap.Rd

Create a heatmap with tracks and dendrograms from any matrix.

plot_heatmap(
  mtx,
  colors = "rocket",
  top_tracks = NULL,
  left_tracks = NULL,
  label = TRUE,
  label_size = NULL,
  rescale = NULL,
  trees = TRUE,
  clust = "complete",
  dist = "euclidean",
  tree_height = NULL,
  track_height = NULL,
  ratio = 1,
  legend = NULL,
  colorbar = NULL,
  ...
)

Arguments

mtx

A numeric matrix with named rows and columns.

colors

A named list() with names matching ".grid", colnames(top_tracks), and colnames(left_tracks). Values in this list should be a palette definition (see section below). Default: "rocket".

For simple cases, a character vector can be given instead of a list. For example, colors = "viridis" is understood to mean the color palette name for the main grid, and colors = c(Age = "magma", Male = "blue", Female = "red") will apply the magma palette to the Age metadata track, and blue and red to the Sex metadata track. The default "rocket" palette will be used for the main grid unless otherwise defined.

To set a custom title in the color scale legend, provide a key prefixed by . like this:

colors = list(.Abundance = list(palette = "rocket", name = "Grid Value").

To reverse the color order in a predefined palette, prepend a hyphen to the name, for example "-rocket".

top_tracks

A data.frame() with row names matching colnames(mtx). Each column will be its own track at the top of the plot. Default: NULL.

left_tracks

A data.frame() with row names matching rownames(mtx). Each column will be its own track at the left of the plot. Default: NULL.

label

Label the matrix rows and columns. You can supply a list or logical vector of length two to control row labels and column labels separately, for example label = c(rows = TRUE, cols = FALSE), or simply label = c(T, F). Other valid options are "rows", "cols", "both", "bottom", "right", and "none". Default: TRUE.

label_size

The font size to use for the row and column labels. You can supply a numeric vector of length two to control row label sizes and column label sizes separately, for example c(rows = 20, cols = 8), or simply c(20, 8). Default: NULL, which computes: pmax(8, pmin(20, 100 / dim(mtx))).

rescale

Rescale rows or columns to all have a common min/max. Options: "rows", "cols", or NULL. Default: NULL (no rescaling).

trees

Draw a dendrogram for rows (left) and columns (top). You can supply a list or logical vector of length two to control the row tree and column tree separately, for example trees = c(rows = T, cols = F), or simply trees = c(T, F). Other valid options are "rows", "cols", "both", "left", "top", and "none". Default: TRUE.

clust

Clustering algorithm for reordering the rows and columns by similarity. You can supply a list or character vector of length two to control the row and column clustering separately, for example clust = c(rows = "complete", cols = NA), or simply clust = c("complete", NA). Default: "complete".

Options are:

  • FALSE or NA - Disable reordering.

  • An hclust object

  • An hclust method name - "ward.D", "ward.D2", "single", "complete", "average", "mcquitty", "median", or "centroid".

dist

Distance algorithm to use when reordering the rows and columns by similarity. You can supply a list or character vector of length two to control the row and column clustering separately, for example dist = c(rows = "euclidean", cols = "maximum"), or simply dist = c("euclidean", "maximum"). Default: dist = "euclidean".

Options are:

  • A dist object

  • A dist method name - "euclidean", "maximum", "manhattan", "canberra", "binary", or "minkowski".

tree_height, track_height

The height of the dendrogram or annotation tracks in multiples (or fractions) of the smaller dimension of the grid cell size. Use a numeric vector of length two to assign c(left, top) independently. Default: NULL, which computes: tree_height = sqrt(min(dim(mtx))), track_height = tree_height / 4.

ratio

Height/width ratio for entire grid. Default: 1 (square).

legend

Where to place the legend. Options are: "right" or "bottom". Default: "right".

Value

A ggplot2 plot. The constructed ggplot command will be attached as attr(,'cmd'), and the underlying computed data as $data.

Palettes

A palette can be as simple as the name of a color set, for example:

colors = "oranges"

You can use any name defined in the paletteer R package, which aggregates color sets from a multitude of other R packages including viridis, RColorBrewer, and ggpubr, to name a few.

Gradients from the viridis and khroma packages have good support for colorblindness: "viridis", "magma", "plasma", "inferno", "cividis", "mako", "rocket", "turbo", "broc", "cork", "vik", "lisbon", "tofino", "berlin", "roma", "turku", "vanimo", "batlow", "devon", "lajolla", "bamako", "davos", "bilbao", "nuuk", "oslo", "grayC", "hawaii", "lapaz", "tokyo", "buda", "acton", "bam", or "imola".

To assign metadata track colors in addition to grid colors, combine them using a list. Any missing definitions will be auto-assigned.

colors = list("oranges", Sex = "wsj_red_green", 'Body Site' = "bugs")

You can also create custom color sets. For categorical data, provide a named character vector of color names. For continuous data, provide an unnamed character vector defining a gradient.

colors = list(Sex = list(palette = c('Male' = "blue", 'Female' = "#FF3390")))

colors = list(Age = list(palette = c("azure", "darkblue", "darkorchid")))

You can also use this nested list structure to pass additional parameters to the underlying ggplot2 discrete_scale or continuous_scale, for example:

colors = list(.grid = list(palette = "turbo", n.breaks = 5, limits = c(0,1), reverse = TRUE, name = "Relative Abundance", na.value = "grey50")

  • name - The title for this color scale in the legend.

  • na.value - The color to use for NA values.

  • limits - The c(min,max) to use for scale values.

  • n.breaks - Bin a gradient into this many bins/steps.

  • reverse - Reverse the order of colors.

See also

Other plotting: adiv_boxplot(), adiv_corrplot(), bdiv_biplot(), bdiv_boxplot(), bdiv_heatmap(), rare_corrplot(), taxa_boxplot(), taxa_corrplot(), taxa_heatmap(), taxa_stacked()

Examples

    library(rbiom)
    
    set.seed(123)
    mtx <- matrix(runif(5*8), nrow = 5)
    rownames(mtx) <- sample(LETTERS, nrow(mtx))
    colnames(mtx) <- sample(letters, ncol(mtx))
    
    plot_heatmap(mtx)

    plot_heatmap(mtx, colors="oranges")

    plot_heatmap(mtx, colors=list(palette = "oranges", name = "New Label", n.breaks = 5))

    
    top_tracks <- data.frame(
      row.names = colnames(mtx), 
      'Bool'    = sample(c(TRUE, FALSE), ncol(mtx), TRUE), 
      'Int'     = sample(1:20,           ncol(mtx), TRUE) )
    left_tracks <- data.frame(
      row.names = rownames(mtx),
      'City'    = sample(names(precip), nrow(mtx)) )
    plot_heatmap(mtx, top_tracks=top_tracks, left_tracks=left_tracks)
